job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: There is a desire to constantly evolve in the university, whether through initiatives, services or communications, and you tend to be a part of this evolution regardless of your position. The NYU culture is also very inclusive and welcoming for administrators. I think your work experience varies depending on the unit/department you work in, but I've had a decent experience in various roles I've been at.
cons: NYU tends to pay admin and staff less than other employers at other institutions. As for pay transparency, NYU tends to have a set budget, so they generally have a particular range they want to hire. I don't see a reason to post huge salary ranges for prospective employees even though that might not be the case. I think career growth isn't the best and even NYU understands that. They encourage you to apply internally to other positions at NYU, but why people shouldn't people have the opportunity to go up the ladder in their department/unit? There is also so much focus on faculty needs and not enough on admin/staff needs.

job_title: Administrative Aide II in New York, NY
pros:
-Solid salary, it was about $52k when I was last there in 2020
-My admin aide II role was union, so on top of having that job security, they bargain for pay increases every few years
-9 to 5 role, because of the union it was actually against the law for me to work more than that
cons:
-Your experience kinda hinges on who you work for. It sound obvious but NYU being a generally good place to work for can be undercut by having a supervisor who isn't great, which was my experience 
-Tuition reimbursement didn't cover as much as you may think, was hard to get straight answers about it and was taken out of your checks (last I checked, which was in 2019, i think it's different now)
-There isn't any real promotional path for admins. If you're an Admin I, you can gain experience then aim for Admin II. If you're already Admin II, you pretty much have to leave to get more money, because the union role prevents any pay raise outside of what's collectively bargained

job_title: Administrative Aide I in New York, NY
pros:
- union position; guaranteed lunch break and two 15 minute breaks. Some departments have you work overtime but if so they then need to comp you or pay you OT.
- university gives a week off between christmas and new years
- winter break is pretty slow as is the summer
- culture really depends on which department you are working in (NYU is such a big school) but most of the people there are very nice and like what they do
- tuition remission for working at a university
cons:
- clocking in and out is annoying and you will be docked pay for every minute you clock in late. Therefore, if I clock in at 9:06am, I then have to clock out at 5:06pm. 
- ability to move up to a different position depends on the department you work for. Some departments are possible, others are not
- check out the job descriptions before you apply. The ones that say something like 'additional tasks as needed' will often mean that your job is whatever the department needs you to help with. This may mean work that technically falls out of your job description and you won't receive additional compensation for it and also can't really refute it since it falls under 'additional tasks.'

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
- Great opportunity to secure a graduate degree at NYU while an employee

- High budgets, no layoffs

- You get to live in NYC

- Great benefits

- Good work life balance

- Lots of Additional fringe benefits (food, events, ticket discounts, etc.)
cons:
- They hire overqualified peoples for jobs at hand which are mostly answer phone calls from a hotline and just being over managed with little to no real quantifiable work assignments. Sending emails occasionally. 

- Administrative bloat at the top leadership that randomly wants to get involved only when it suites their individual/personal interests.

- Toxic work environment and psychologically unsafe; never able to voice your true ideas in meetings. They preach openness and inclusion but it was quite the opposite. There was constant and deliberate inappropriate interactions/statements/talk from certain employees that was never addressed by leadership.

- Pretty technologically backwards and slow to adopt things that will increase efficiency. They seem to like to remain antiquated and wasteful 

- They promote and allow the throwing of others under the bus, and most are only concerned with managing up and not supporting those underneath. It is not a collaborative environment. There are many good people but they are all fearful of speaking up and have just learned to keep their head down which unfortunately perpetuates the toxic environment. 

- Overall sense of fear and intimidation tactics are used and nepotism 

- Low raises

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Their brand name is quite strong, the labs are well equipped, the faculty is world renowned.
cons:
I was warned by several people in my profession (senior and junior faculty members and postdocs alike) about the abusive environment in the Adolph lab at NYU, but I had to see it to believe it. Basic lab operations are inscrutably Machiavellian for no good reason, there is no transparency, the PI and her close friend and co-author openly denigrate other senior scientists in the field in the presence of young students (including undergrads), favoritism towards a certain long-standing researcher is rampant, and there seems to be no real system for feedback or improvement of status quo. 

As for the culture, working through the lunch hour and eating "lunch" at 6pm before working for a few hours before leaving for home is common. Over half the students/researchers in this lab regularly see therapists to deal with their specific lab-induced stress. It is honestly a scary place for anyone, particularly those early in their careers, to be in.

job_title: Procurement in New York, NY
pros: work-life balance is great and the location was good. Also my peers in the group were great people.
cons:
I had worked in procurement/sourcing for years and was told every year that I barely met expectations and as such I never received any more than 1.25% raise. I would ask how I could improve or why I could not get any more of a raise and I was always simply told I needed to do more. I needed to work on more high-profile projects. Eventually, I did come up with a very high-profile, value-add project and then was told I would not be given the tools or training to complete. So of course, when it came time for evaluations, I was once again told to do more and cited my lack of project completion as why I would not be getting more of a raise.

Leadership was also seriously lacking, no direction was ever given and no processes were ever documented or put in place. If you asked any leaders what the protocol for something was, they would be very vague and nebulous. And if something happened, fingers were always pointed but no processes would be put in place to mitigate future occurrences. Same with all projects, I had asked many times for feedback and direction as well as my peers and the only feedback ever given were random word misspellings or incorrect font usage on the presentations.

Most infuriating of it all was that I was told I could never email any director-level internal employees or higher unless my own director had proof-read them. I had worked in many companies and this is the most bizarre and ludicrous rule I've ever come across. 

The director here leads by fear and is of the mentality that you're lucky you even have a job. By telling us that we are not that great at our jobs and therefore not worthy of raises and making us believe it, is simply fear-mongering. We are not given any support at all. When we meet with leadership on blockers for projects or initiatives we are simply told to 'do better'. I ultimately left and it turns out that I wasn't bad at my job after all and had a very marketable skill set-- I currently make 3x what I used to here.

job_title: Procurement in New York, NY
pros: Most of the people were great to be around and get to know. Very good benefits as well, including on the 401k match and additional contribution. Work life balance was also important. My second manager was very good - he actually seemed to have a plan in place and took time to teach me things.
cons:
A couple months after I started, it became obvious that there were certain people high up on the ladder who had no business being at the level they were at. 

I mentioned how good my second manager was - that's partly because of how terrible and inefficient my first and third managers were in my time there. I had a second manager because I needed to transfer away from the first one. Had a third manager because the second one was promoted to a well-deserved new role. The overall structure of the department is a mess and makes zero sense, there's no training or actual guidance from so-called leadership, and it doesn't even look like a plan is in place going forward. Anyone with good ideas to move things forward and progress would see those ideas be neglected almost instantly. 

I wasn't stressed out by the job, I was just frustrated by the lack of competency and leadership, and seemingly the lack of everything else that would make a department successful. There was no future here, and I was just treading water basically - so I cut my losses and got out. If I didn't get transferred to my second hiring manager, I would've been gone sooner. 

I was excited to get the job at NYU initially, and within three months of starting, I was trying to leave. There were at least four other people who were in my position before me, and the longest any of them lasted was a year and a half. That should tell you everything you need to know.

pros: NYU is a great place to work for those that have ambitions to go to graduate school. Their tuition remission benefit is fantastic and is the top reason I think someone should join the institution.
cons: In order to grow, you must move departments, as there are few opportunities for career advancement. As in many universities, the students and faculty come first. Staff and administration have minimal say, and many times, I felt underpaid, under-appreciated, and unprotected. Even if you are fortunate to become an adjunct faculty member, you don't get protections of a faculty member. For example, an employee can be terminated much more quickly than a full time faculty member.

review_title: Exciting, Student Facing, Fast Paced, Educational, Administratively Robust
job_title: Residence Hall Director in New York, NY
pros: Ample student interaction, great location, a lot of perks in the city for being an NYU employee, great benefits, positive atmosphere of community, a large school with resources, a network of interesting faculty and staff. Part of the compensation beyond your salary includes an apartment within the residence halls and a meal plan on campus. Strong on diversity, equity, inclusion. A lot of movement between your office, the campus, visiting other offices, and some light remote work from time to time. Management really listens, and solicits feedback. It's apparent that they make changes willingly based on the feedback of staff, students, stakeholders.
cons: If you do not want to live-in and manage a university residence hall, this is not for you. You live in a fish bowl, and students are looking to you for role modeling. The pace is also quite fast and heavy. One must be task-efficient with critical thinking, strong electronic and verbal communication. Must think quick on your feet, which is a good thing if you like that environment. You may often work an hour or two beyond your office hours. This job, by it's nature, cannot be remote 100%. You are an essential staff member, which means being physically present.

job_title: Administrative Aide II in New York, NY
pros: Working at New York University as an Administrative Aide is very fair for what you get. I work full time and I am working towards my Master's degree at NYU. I get 100% of tuition covered. I only pay half of student fees. Health insurance is wonderful, and there are many other benefits of being part of such a large employee base.
cons: The job itself is not the most fulfilling, and I am often left feeling like there is not a path forward in my career. I am also not eligible to receive a raise beyond that of the annual increase negotiated through the union. Unfortunately, this leaves me with very little motivation. The pandemic has only complicated all of these things more, but overall, I am grateful to be in school, debt-free, and receiving a decent salary.

job_title: Anonymous in New York, NY
pros:
- the world class reputation of the school can help your resume 
- tuition remission! (90% off tuition for a Master's) 
- if you are working in admissions, departments expect a lot of independence for travel 
- holiday and vacation days 
- for admissions offices: if you are not in the recruitment season, expect a standard 9 to 5 (during recruitment, expect to work up to 70 hours per week)
cons:
- low pay for the amount of work you put in
- no bonuses or financial incentive (2.0% salary raises do not even keep up with the rate of inflation and rise in cost of living) 
- management at SPS is awful, horrible retention rate because lack of true leadership. so many times, supervisors have chosen to play the 'blame game' without any accountability 
- unrealistic budget constraints for heavy travel with recruitment (this is the first time that I've paid to work at my own job) 
- AP Workflow is a nightmare, expect reimbursements to be scrutinized and take a couple of weeks while your credit card fees pile up 
- workload during recruitment can be intense, especially because the office cannot turn away walk-in students 
- ATS system has a lot of fundamental errors which makes it difficult to appropriately track applications 
- hit or miss when it comes to career opportunities- I've seen coworkers move to different departments and grow with a better title change...on the other hand, I witnessed others stay in SPS for YEARS without even a chance of upward mobility
